Why you should not trust youtube shills:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Twy5Wo8m284

If you have any additional questions, ask them.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

last_replies.com:
>>6376324
I don't mean to rag on you, because it's a good effort overall, but her snout is pretty massively fucked. It's off-centre, too thin, and just all around kind of wonky, so I'd recommend looking into how your favorite artists draw snouts, and maybe studying some anatomy on them. Her eyes also appear very flat, as if her face is a plane, and not a volume; you should decide if they're on the front of her face, and then study those types of skulls, or on the sides, like a prey animal or a dinosaur. The way her cheek shows on one side is inaccurate as well.

Faces are tough, especially non-human ones. Keep at it.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6376117
This guy isn't me.

>>6376102
>I've always wanted to try Prismacolors over Copics, what set of markers would you recommend?
I started off with the Cool Greys that were sold to me in art school. Later on, I bought the 48 color pack, the Warm Greys pack & others.

If you have the money, I would suggest buying the 48 Color Pack, both Warm & Cool Greys, & the Skin Tones pack. Don't make the mistake of thinking you won't need any "redundant" markers, they'll dry up on you if you use them often enough. They're pretty expensive, so scour the internet for any coupons you can use for blick or AC Moore. I saved a small fortune with a 50% off coupon once.

Oh, & ALWAYS make sure that the caps are SECURELY ON when you aren't using them. That, & the ones that have been made in the past decade have these weird caps that make it hard to pull off, so twist them, DON'T pull. You could damage you fingers & the marker.

>And what type of paper weight are you using for your color?
Canson Mixed Media. Basically, use any mixed media paper, HOWEVER, make sure to slide a sheet of printer paper under it. A lot of the time, the markers will bleed through the paper, & even seep into the page below.

Got any leather belts with detailing on them? or a buckle? Just putting it in front of you and practicing painting from that would help you get there. Pay attention to light source, edges and specular highlights.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6376111
http://gurneyjourney.blogspot.com/2008/04/hair-ribbon-secret.html

Prepare to level up, OP. Take this method, and apply it to metal surfaces to accentuate their forms, and textures.

The key thing here is that you take a surface and you add a highlight across the form that catches the light. Again - key word here is across.

You can technically apply this to anything. Playing with the sharpness, size & the amount of the highlight will help better describe the shininess (or dullness) of the metal or any other material.

For an example, look at your top right drawing. You see there is a line of light that is going across her body from the bottom left (thigh metal) to the top right (by her neck). You can also see that this streak of light is represented on the material of her suit, but it's much more subdued.

Hope this helps!

>>6375316
First thing doing the 250 box challenge from Drawabox. The trial and error approach of the exercise made me internalize perspective.

Second thing was understanding the lighting equation. It gave me intuition about how light works.

The last thing up so far was the chapter 3 of the book "Drawing in the Digital Age: An Observational Method for Artists and Animators". The method it teaches almost instantly improved my eyeball accuracy.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
while i don't do forgeries, i know what it takes to make them.
you're better off familiarising yourself with the materials and techniques through technical reports and period literature. a lot of the forgers before the kind of research we have now are actually very off-base.
think about things like fasteners if it uses them. wood an joinery methods. what kind of tools were made. want to make a painting on joined panel? better know how to join wood using period tools and glue. does the paint use lake pigments? know the difference between earlier methods and 19th century methods. if you are doing 17th century works on paper, you can buy period blank paper on ebay.
national gallery technical bulletin is good. getty museum publishes conservation literature as well through their research institute and i'm sure other museums do as well, but they are sort of known for their conservation. however, be prepared that a lot of conservation works is not the same as doing the works themselves.

That's dialectical thinking and not everything is dialectically-oriented but Form could mean many things like the direction of a film, or the arrangement of flowers in a vase, I like gestalt as an explanation of form, but in consideration of a still life you might see it as the sum of its most basic parts like colour, shape, weight, texture, lighting. In art Copying is time or measurement based; Form is a configuration of spatial interrogation which grants the art its more 'complete' feeling. Sort of how Poetry has its various standards of metre. It's an elusive configuration of decision points. For many people the principles of the Shinto religion or the Psalms or the Quran might underly their understanding of Form but in the non-verbal arts it's not easily explicated and is always going to remain somewhat mysterious.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6375078
if lead is only a trace element in zinc, imagine how little is in titanium wtth 2-5% zinc. painting with cadmium colors is so much more dangerous at that point.
there's a number of inert pigments that are mostly transparent in the average layer of oil paint you can add to make any pigment more transparent.
calcium carbonate (chalk, egg shells, marble, limestone), silica (crushed glass, pumice, silica-rich sand, quartz). calcium carbonate is safer because silica can damage lungs much more. make a paint mixing the transparent pigment with oil to a consistency you like and add it to your tube paint, or add chalk directly and add oil if it is too lean.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6375089
>By the way, just HOW dangerous is Lead white if you don't grind it yourself? For example are you in trouble if you get it on your skin while painting?
Not in quantities you'd use if it happens a couple of times, but over time you could get yourself in trouble. Lead doesn't really leave your body basically ever once it gets in. By itself, anyway: you can get rid of most of it with Dimercaprol.

If you get it in your food somehow, either by having it in your fingers (Even if it's so little as to not show clearly) or clothes or whatever, that's actually bad. That's why it's recommended to use gloves (Nitrile only: Latex can get dissolved by oil/solvents) and to never eat/drink while in the studio if working with lead white.

Mostly it's a case of "better safe than sorry", but there's genuine long-term health risks that many underestimate.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Learn how to measure. An anon suggested Bargue, which works but may start off too complicated for you. Look up some cubes or rectangular prisms and see if you can make the correct marks. then move to some beginner Bargue plates. Remember to get people to check where your measuring went wrong by having both your drawing and the original subject.

Avoid adding superficial elements to your drawing when doing these exercises. For a proportional drawing, do not bother shading or worry about subtle line quality. Focus on proportional relationships. After you get that down, add something on top of that like gesture.

Watch some videos on how to measure off youtube. Proko and Dorian Iten got some on their channels. Get real comfortable with the techniques, you'll be practicing them for as long as you draw. Remember to draw for fun and draw what you like.

Pic related is a cast study I did recently.

I did some experiments setting up 3D models in VR with a desktop drawing app displayed on top and using a screenless tablet to draw them. I came to the conclusion that this is absolutely the future of drawing education. The ability to study literally anything imaginable as though its 3D form were sitting right in front of you, displayed at any angle or distance, is absolutely incredible. However, I think that the best implementation of this would be with mixed reality, where you can see the 3D model overlayed in the real world and draw on physical paper in front of you. The Quest Pro is already going in this direction so I imagine it will eventually become feasible.

>>6367801
When someone praises me I usually respond with criticism of them, ideally in the same domain but if they aren't active there I'll try to find something as close as possible in which they are.
Praise is traditionally considered a signal that they have recognized your superiority in some respect. When this is the case, by criticizing them in turn you are recognizing their inferiority, reinforcing and protecting your place in the hierarchy.
However, note I said "traditionally" because despite that common understanding, typically people praise for the opposite reason: a patronizing sentiment to signal that they are ABOVE you. In this case, criticizing becomes even more critically useful as it closes that gap and indicates that you understand their flaws and thus their vulnerabilities; a warning that you are not to be trifled with and a direct rebuke to their assumed superiority.

I see many people focusing 95% of their output on the former without considering the latter (and they said their goal is to draw from imagination...), and those people usually take a shitton of years to get out of beg. On the other side, I noticed that the people who mainly do 75% personal work and 25% drawing from life + studying other artists while also not having a specific comfort zone tend to improve at very quick rates if they keep at it.
Is this the ultimate redpill?

I don't know about loomis heads, but the 250 boxes challenge from Drawabox was THE exercise which made me internalize perspective. It became way easier to reason about it after the exercise.
